video.title: How to Build a RESTful API using Node, Express, and Mongo
video.description:
A REST API is an integral component of a web application. You don't need to be an expert backend developer to make your own. In this workshop, we will walk through the basic building blocks of creating your own REST API using Node.js, Express, and MongoDB.

🔗Slide Deck: https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1VSlo9JEsoVjNNH4DqOJtSWInKIis5p39lmHvAcLifSw
🔗Github Repo: https://github.com/theoutlander/rest-api-workshop

Tutorial from Nick Karnik. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UClCm-WAOgN6XLwCpefSVezg

Nick on Twitter: https://twitter.com/theoutlander

This video was originally a live stream.

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Leo Buckey
topLevelComment.text: I'm sorry for such an amateurish question but why do you not end your JavaScript statements with semicolons (;)?

replies.author: Lauren Bridges
replies.text: Mike Hodges thanks Mike:)

replies.author: Mike Hodges
replies.text: @Lauren Bridges ES6 is JS... It's more of a nodejs/express convention than anything. Everyone writing ES6+ on the client-side uses semicolons.

replies.author: Lauren Bridges
replies.text: It's not an amateurish question. It's a difference between ES6 and JS...For ES6: "Include semi-colons at the end of each line that is a variable declaration using const, let, or var. Do NOT include semi-colons at the end of function declarations, loops, classes, and constructors..."

replies.author: Nick Karnik
replies.text: 80Vikram  I would focus on learning how to build backend services first and over time you will learn about the pros/cons of a microservice vs. monolith. To start, you should only work with monolithic services as they have a low overhead compared to microservices. There are plenty of resources out there. I would recommend reading through medium.freecodecamp.org, dev.to, codeburst.io, and the various youtube channels including freeCodeCamp. Beau has some great tutorials on this channel as well. You also can check out Wes Bos & Scott Tolinski's youtube channels, LearnCode.academy, etc. I'm also working on more videos, so feel free to suggest topics that you are interested in. Thanks!

replies.author: Nick Karnik
replies.text: Hi Vikram! The server-side is client agnostic. You can follow the same server-side pattern for mobile development. As for cloud deployment, my favorite is Now.sh and I would highly recommend it. I've also used AWS & Azure heavily, which seem to be too much of a headache for smaller projects. If you go the AWS route, I'd recommend Elastic Beanstalk instead of directly configuring EC2. Linode and DigitalOcean are also great inexpensive options. Hope that helps.
